headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is John and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the DuPont 2010 First Quarter Investor Call. [Operator Instructions] It's now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Ka
componenttext: Good morning. My name is John and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the DuPont 2010 First Quarter Investor Call. [Operator Instructions] It's now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Karen Fletcher, Vice President of Investor Relations. Madame, you may begin your conference.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good morning and welcome. With me this morning are Ellen Kullman, Chair and CEO; and Nick Fanandakis, CFO. The slides for today's call can be found on our website at www.dupont.com, along with the news release that was issued earlier toda
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good morning and welcome. With me this morning are Ellen Kullman, Chair and CEO; and Nick Fanandakis, CFO. The slides for today's call can be found on our website at www.dupont.com, along with the news release that was issued earlier today.
Please turn to Slide 1. During the course of this conference call, we will make forward-looking statements. All statements that address expectations or projections about the future are forward-looking statements. Although they reflect our current expectations, these statements are not guarantees of future performance, but involve a number of risks and assumptions. We urge you to review DuPont's SEC filings for a discussion of some of the factors that could cause actual results to differ materially. We will also refer to non-GAAP measures and request that you please refer to the reconciliations to GAAP statements provided with our earnings news release and on our website. And finally, we've posted supplemental information on our website that we hope is helpful to your understanding of our company's performance.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Ellen.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Karen, and good morning everyone. This time last year, we were taking aggressive actions to respond to deteriorating market conditions. Our initiatives were aimed at enhancing near-term profitability while preparing to respond to the economic reco
componenttext:
Thanks, Karen, and good morning everyone. This time last year, we were taking aggressive actions to respond to deteriorating market conditions. Our initiatives were aimed at enhancing near-term profitability while preparing to respond to the economic recovery when it came. Today, those actions are paying off in the form of streamlined business units, a lower cost base, and just as important, much greater customer intimacy, with an ability to respond faster to customer demands. During the first quarter, we delivered strong results of $1.24 earnings per share, more than double the first quarter of 2009 and just $0.07 below the first quarter of 2008. I am very pleased with our performance, the way we responded to changing market demands and our momentum going forward.
The forecast for 2010 global industrial production is about a 7% improvement, with recovery rates that vary greatly by country and by industry. Many of our polymers and chemical businesses saw strong demand pick up in the first quarter, magnified by the comparison to a particularly weak first quarter of 2009. Because we stayed close to our customers and supply chains, we could better anticipate demand signals. In some cases, our management teams made conscious, thoughtful business decisions to take on cost in order to keep pace with a strong pickup in demand.
Two cases in point, Performance Chemicals and Performance Materials, had volume increases of 30% and 56% respectively. Their supply chains were already tight and these businesses skillfully managed significant challenges to produce and deliver product to keep up with market demand. They were able to because our customer relationships gave us better visibility in the markets, and we were able to anticipate demand signals.
We believe we were better equipped to meet demands than our competitors and in some cases gained market share as a result. Pretax operating margins of 13% to 15% in these two reporting units reflect higher operating rates coupled with the leverage from outstanding work to take out cost over the past 18 months. Estimates for 2010 light vehicle production increased since I spoke to you last quarter. In January, we expected global production to be up 9%. Our current view is a 13% increase for the year. In the first quarter, vehicle production was up nearly 40% against a very weak year-over-year comp. DuPont Performance Coatings stepped up to market demands and we saw their earnings improve from a loss of $75 million in the first quarter of 2009 to a profit of $45 million this quarter. With 5% pretax operating margin in the quarter, it's clear that there's still work to do. However, I'm pleased with the progress this segment has achieved against formidable challenges.
They've displayed dedication and determination as they continue to drive this business towards world class status. Demand for consumer electronics continued strong heading into the first quarter, which we anticipated. Demand for photovoltaics surged beyond our expectations, driven by new government stimulus programs, advanced buying ahead of Germany's feed-in tariff reduction and pent-up demand from last year. In addition to meeting strong orders, we continued to introduce new products with added value through increased efficiency, enhanced performance, and cost effectiveness. Electronics & Communications R&D spend is about 7% of sales, well above the company average, because our product offering and the value it brings to PV differentiates DuPont. DuPont sales into PV are so strong that we now expect to surpass $1 billion in 2011, one full year ahead of plan.
Our Safety & Protection segment lagged into the recession, but stabilized during the fourth quarter. We're starting to see these businesses improve. Increases in motor vehicle builds and industrial production supported modest sales growth, while outstanding work by our teams
[Audio Gap]
Global construction markets remain soft and, therefore, we focused on differentiating ourselves with new products and increasing market penetration in both developed and emerging markets. Our global Corian product launches have gone very well and we're actually growing Tyvek and Surfaces sales into commercial markets that are still in decline. Overall, new products and applications will help grow sales in Safety & Protection into the mid teens in 2010. Of course another important market for DuPont is agriculture. We have tremendous momentum in our Seed business, particularly in North America, where sales in this region topped $3 billion in 2009, nearly doubling in size in three years. Our momentum was hard earned, with product performance and investments in R&D and sales and marketing. We've executed a sustainable business model that focuses on the right product for the right acre, an approach that benefits our customers and translates into greater value for DuPont shareholders. While first quarter results reflect some seasonal shifts between quarters, the outlook for the Northern Hemisphere planting season remains very strong and we still expect to gain one to two points of global seed market share in 2010.
One final comment on our markets this quarter. Company sales in Asia were up 71% to $1.6 billion. Not only was this a record for that region sales in the first quarter but they were over 20% higher than the prior record set in the first quarter of 2008. There were many standout achievements, including a doubling of sales in Japan and Korea in to electronics and automotive markets. I was in Asia last month and witnessed our team's intense focus on the customer and their passion for DuPont's offerings. I visited our Hyderabad technical center in India and reviewed several customer development projects, which coupled with our intimate knowledge of local market needs with DuPont innovation. Regional technical centers like Hyderabad or Shenzhen, China or Pollinia, Brazil provide gateways to local opportunities, supported with the power of DuPont and its R&D engine. That's one reason sales in emerging markets were up 33% in the first quarter. This success is reflective of a strong foundation in these important growth markets, coupled with highly attractive offering and bodes well for continued growth.
Now I'm going to turn the call over to Nick to review our financial performance, and then I'll close the call with comments on our outlook. Nick?

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ellen and good morning, everyone. I'm delighted to report to you that DuPont has delivered very strong results for the first quarter performance. As the global economy recovers, we drove volume and price up in all regions. This is an outstandin
componenttext:
Thank you, Ellen and good morning, everyone. I'm delighted to report to you that DuPont has delivered very strong results for the first quarter performance. As the global economy recovers, we drove volume and price up in all regions. This is an outstanding start to what we expect to be a pivotal year for the DuPont Company as we replaced pharmaceutical royalties with growth from all other business units. By almost any measure, it's a solid encouraging performance, especially in light of a still recovering global economy. Our teams around the world delivered on their commitments to grow revenue and generate earnings while continuing to drive cost and capital productivity, all the while staying close to customers, their expectations and their changing needs. I characterize these as encouraging results because I believe this to be a great start to what we all expect to be a very good year for DuPont. I sense real momentum from all of our business leaders.
Given the challenges we faced last year, which I know at times seem very overwhelming, it's a great feeling to know that this company is emerging stronger, more competitive and ready to go the distance. We delivered on the first quarter and we're poised for growth throughout 2010. Now I'd like to review the details of the quarter, pointing out our accomplishments versus goals, as well as how our actions are continuing transition from a recessionary environment to one of growth.
Let's go to Slide 2. It summarizes earnings per share and sales results. First quarter reported earnings per share were $1.24, up more than twice our earnings of $0.54 in the prior year. Consolidated net sales of $8.5 billion were up 23% compared to the prior year, reflecting a 19% volume improvement, 2% price increase, 3% favorable currency affect and a 1% reduction from some small portfolio changes. Volume was up in all business segments and in all regions of the world. Local currency prices were also up, reflecting our sustained robust pricing discipline.
Starting our segment review with Ag & Nutrition, on Slide 3, you see that sales grew 6% to $3.2 billion and earnings grew 10% to $941 million, resulting in over 100 basis point pretax margin expansion versus the same period last year. Seed sales in the quarter reached $2.2 billion, an increase of 8%, with 7% U.S. dollar price gains and 1% higher volume. As Ellen mentioned, the clear driver was the tremendous success we continued to experience in North America, where sales growth was greater than 15%, underpinned by volume and price improvements. With sales volumes higher by about 10%, we're expecting share gains in corn and soybeans. The exact share gains will obviously depend on the final acres planted. At this point in the season, the orders are in and we are working on in season opportunities. This is yet another example where our direct sales organization and supply chain capability really thrives. Our sales force is out there working with the growers, responding to late planting opportunities and optimizing inventories so the farmer gets exactly what he needs.
Turning to Europe, here, the farm economy is slow to recover after the global downturn. This is holding commodity prices down and resulting in flat to slightly reduced plantings in both corn and sunflowers, and contributing to intense competition in the marketplace. All of this, together with a late start to the season, resulted in European Seed sales being down significantly in the quarter, the implication being that we will see some volume shift into the second quarter.
In Latin America, we captured price and volume gains for the Sabrina season. Price gains reflected industry-leading BT penetration to about 48% of our sales in Brazil. Volume gains, which favored fourth quarter, reflect share gain on slightly increased acreage. Before turning to crop protection, I want to give you a brief update on AcreMax 1 plans. We don't have the EPA approval today, but we anticipate a positive EPA decision within a week. For 2010 planning, our objective is to demonstrate the product value with farmers in the fields, setting the stage for a 2011 commercial launch. To that end, we have product in over 2,600 plots, strategically placed, allowing thousands of farmers to experience the performance during 2010 planting.
Now let's turn to crop protection. In crop protection, product sales were up slightly as favorable currency offset lower volumes and local prices, as well as portfolio change. The anticipated competitive pricing pressure was fairly broad based. The volume decline reflects seasonal timing shifts to the second quarter, which was partially offset by the continued growth of Rynaxypyr. Rynaxypyr growth continues at a fast pace as we confidently move toward our 2010 goal of $300 million in sales, a 50% increase over that in 2009. This product was the first launched from a reinvigorated crop protection pipeline, and we're making the right decisions to deliver the next blockbuster products, such as Plainview, a broad spectrum bare ground wheat control, or, Cyazypyr, an insecticide.
Our Nutrition and Health business continued their transformation work of delivering high, higher value offerings, which produced increased sales and earnings from same period previous year. Looking ahead to the second quarter for Ag & Nutrition reporting segment, we expect sales and earnings to increase significantly versus same period previous year.
[Audio Gap]
The Performance Chemicals segment. Sales of $1.4 billion increased $344 million or 32%, reflecting 30% increase in volumes, 3% higher selling prices and a 1% reduction due to portfolio changes. The sales increase was principally driven by strong recovery that continues in the titanium dioxide business and the flouropolymer markets in all regions and strong demand for all refrigerants including strong adoption rates for ISCEON as a preferred retrofit for R22.
PTOI was $190 million, an improvement of $146 million, primarily due to these higher volumes. Looking ahead to the second quarter, sales and earnings are expected to be up substantially year-over-year due to the improved economic conditions in most markets. Sequentially, we expect sales to be modestly up and earnings to be significantly up, reflecting a strong recovery that continues in most markets and the seasonal uptick in demand for Tio2 and refrigerants, along with very strong demand for ISCEON in the European region.
Now let's turn to Slide 6, Performance Coatings. Segment sales of $902 million increased $170 million or 23%. Sales increased as a result of 17% stronger volumes, as well as some pricing gains. Demand was driven by continued recovery in the global automotive market as well as a strong rebound in Asia-Pacific. PTOI was $45 million, up $120 million from the prior year. The improvement was primarily led by this increased volume, lower raw material costs and aggressive fixed cost reductions. Segment sales in Asia-Pacific continued to recover, up 45% versus prior year's first quarter. Global auto builds were up 39% led by North America, which was up 68% versus prior year. For the full year, we are now expecting global auto builds to be about 13% increase and as Ellen stated, this is an increase from our prior estimate of 9% and in line with the stronger volumes that we saw this quarter.
While auto builds have not returned to the pre-recessionary levels, and we don't expect them to until 2011, the strength we're seeing in emerging markets is offsetting declines in developed markets.
Looking ahead to the second quarter for our Performance Coatings, we expect sales to be up significantly year-over-year. Demand for OEM paints should improve with increases in global vehicle production. Both OEM and Refinish Paint products should benefit from continued improvement in consumer confidence in developed regions around the world. And positive momentum should continue in emerging markets. Sequentially, sales should be moderately up as a function of higher demand in automotives and Refinish Paint products. We expect earnings to be substantially up in the second quarter versus prior year. Lower costs should also have a positive effect. Sequentially, we expect earnings to be up on higher sales as automotive aftermarket momentum continues, partially offset by rising raw material costs.
Let's turn now to Performance Materials segment on Slide 7. Sales of $1.5 billion increased $592 million or 63%, reflecting 56% higher volumes and 7% increases in selling prices. Higher volumes reflect improvements in automotive, industrial, consumer and the electronics markets, with strong recovery in all regions led by Asia-Pacific and Europe.
PTOI was $230 million, an improvement of $376 million. We delivered strong volume growth in all regions, as well as margin expansion, with lower raw material costs, higher selling prices, favorable currency and improved fixed cost productivity.
Looking ahead for the second quarter, sales and earnings are expected to be up substantially year-over-year, reflecting improved conditions in most markets. Sequentially, we expect sales to be essentially flat and earnings to be down, reflecting the higher raw material costs.
Let's look at Slide 8, and here you see the Safety & Protection segment. Sales of $789 million increased $71 million or 10%, principally reflecting an 8% increase in volume and 2% higher selling prices. The volume increase was primarily due to recovery in automotives and industrial markets, coupled with moderate strengthening in construction markets. PTOI was $102 million, an improvement of $38 million, reflecting higher volumes and lower raw material costs. Looking ahead to the second quarter, sales and earnings are expected to be up substantially year-over-year. We anticipate improved demand for industrial, auto and construction markets. Sequentially, we expect sales to be up modestly and earnings to be up slightly, reflecting continued recovery in the industrial and automotive markets.
Now, let's turn to the corporate view of the first quarter earnings per share variance analysis that you see on Slide 9. Looking at price and variable costs, the quarter showed a net benefit of $0.21 per share. This reflects the positive spread between price and variable costs, excluding the impact of currency and volume. Again, excluding volume currency and portfolio impacts, first quarter variable costs were down about 2%. We anticipate that the full year 2010 variable costs will increase about 5% over 2009. And looking from a quarter by quarter perspective, we believe that the first quarter was the final quarter that we'll see a reduction year-over-year and we expect the trend to reverse for the remaining quarters of 2010. Volume improvement resulted in an incremental earnings benefit of $0.57 per share compared to the same period previous year, in part reflecting the benefits from increased capacity utilization.
As I mentioned earlier, this benefit is broadly based across all businesses and regions and was particularly strong in Asia, up 65%. There's a graph that you can see depicting sales by geography region shown on Slide 10.
Continuing on with variance analysis, let's move to the fixed costs. Excluding volume and currency, fixed cost reduced earnings by $0.14 cents a share in the quarter. Included in that calculation is an $0.08 incremental pension charge along with actions in the first quarter to support growth such as targeted increases of contractors as production ramps up, increased investments in Seed R&D and specific marketing initiatives. Concurrent with the actions that we're taking to support growth, we estimate that DuPont realized about $130 million of savings in the quarter due to our cost reduction programs. In 2010, we have committed to deliver $400 million in fixed cost productivity reductions and $200 million of incremental restructuring benefit. We will deliver on these savings. We used a managing process for which I am personally responsible that evaluates growth initiative proposals and tracks progress on cost productivity programs. Clearly with volumes rebounding so strongly we are adding back resources to support this volume growth and remain firm in our resolve to do so thoughtfully and only when higher volume dictates the need.
Year-over-year currency was a tailwind of $0.10, reflecting an 8% weaker dollar in the quarter. We believe this will turn into a headwind for the second half of the year. In the other category, on the waterfall chart, reduced earnings by $0.04 per share. This includes a $0.02 charge for exchange gains and losses. $36 million charge was the impact of the Venezuela devaluation and is included in this exchange gains and loss. Our goal continues to be to achieve zero after-tax impact from our balance sheet hedging program. As is typical, the detailed reconciliation is on Schedule D to show you the exact impact of our hedging program had on the effective tax rate and on earnings. This other category also includes a $0.02 reduction in Pharmaceutical earnings. First quarter Pharma earnings were $221 million, about $30 million below the same period last year. While Pharmaceutical earnings were below prior year, they were better than expected and as a result, we are increasing our 2010 range for Pharma pretax earnings to $360 million to $400 million. We expect the remaining earnings to be spread evenly over the balance of the year. There are assumptions and uncertainties to this forecast such as the generic erosion curve in both the U.S. and Europe, estimated inventory levels and contractual elements.
The last point on the EPS waterfall chart is our first quarter 2010 base tax rate, which was 23.4% versus 23.1% first quarter prior year, which created a net zero EPS impact. Looking forward, we estimate the full year 2010 base tax rate to be 23% to 24%.
Turning now to the balance sheet and cash on Slide 11. First quarter free cash flow was a seasonal outflow of $1.3 billion. Higher net income was offset by increases in working capital to support strong volume growth. For example, our Electronic & Communication segment had volume growth of 60% and Performance Materials volume increased by 56%. We are also preparing for a significant sales increase in our titanium dioxide, refinished coatings and refrigerant products as we move into their seasonally strong second quarter. As you recall, we have committed to a $1 billion working capital productivity gain over the next three years. Based on networking capital levels, we are on track to deliver $400 million of that in 2010. Here again, I'm leading a managing process around working capital productivity to ensure that we deliver on these commitments.
Regarding dividends, with a dividend payment in March, we have paid 422 consecutive dividends. Our strategy has been to drive hard, delivering cash returns to our investors. So in summary, for the first quarter, the year-over-year volume growth that started in the fourth quarter of 2009 continued and expanded in the first quarter, exceeding our expectations. This along with our pricing discipline and productivity focus, delivered strong quarterly results.
Turning now to the second quarter 2010. We expect the recovery that we've seen in our businesses to continue, along with projected strength and growth in the Ag & Nutrition segment, which is underpinned by a solid finish to the Northern Hemisphere planting. For the full year 2010, DuPont's leadership team remains confident in our business plans and our ability to execute against the plan. We're raising our guidance from a range of $2.15 to $2.45 per share to a range of $2.50 to $2.70 per share based upon the strong results in the first quarter and our ability to execute the very compelling growth plan we've laid out for our investors through 2012. The updated guidance puts our earnings per share growth at 20% to 35% versus 2009.
On Slide 12, looking strictly at pretax operating income excluding significant items, we anticipate more than 20% growth, and if you exclude Pharma from these results, our growth is greater than 50%. In line with our increased earnings, we are raising our outlook for 2010 full year free cash flow to greater than $1.7 billion from our previous outlook of greater than $1.5 billion. This reflects higher cash earnings and continued productivity. As I said at the start, we have a plan for 2010 and we will execute against that plan, which is in short, grow our business across the globe and expand our margins. We're off to an excellent start to what should be a great year for the DuPont Co. With that, Ellen, I'll turn it back to you.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you, Nick. I'd like to reinforce what Nick just said. When we met with investors last November, each one of our reporting units outlined its business mission, priorities, and growth targets through 2012. Our plan is working. Results so far re
componenttext:
Great, thank you, Nick. I'd like to reinforce what Nick just said. When we met with investors last November, each one of our reporting units outlined its business mission, priorities, and growth targets through 2012. Our plan is working. Results so far reinforce our confidence that we can meet or exceed our 2012 goals. $1.24 first quarter earnings per share was not the product of this quarter alone. It's the result of the last six quarters' worth of efforts in terms of restructuring, fixed and variable cost productivity, working capital productivity and most importantly, staying close to our customers and markets. We've effectively been repositioning the company for the recovery that's underway right now. As for our Ag business, you can expect continued growth and margin expansion. We remain committed to deliver 15% segment earnings growth compounded annually through 2013. Of course, half our sales for this segment are in Seeds, where we see the biggest growth opportunities. The Pioneer North American leadership team has successfully implemented its reinvestment strategy, building a sales and agronomy force numbering more than 4,000 strong, complemented by an industry-leading portfolio of products. We have a track record of growth in international Seed as well and continue to build on that position. We have a strong R&D pipeline and are committed to pricing for value, supported by growers who have benefited greatly from our product innovations tailored to their needs and local conditions. In the end, this strategy has delivered volume and price gains, which resulted in strong earnings growth and will continue to do so.
Please turn to Slide 13. In summary, we remain focused on execution. Our priorities are outlined on this slide in the form of directives, which are broadly shared with employees. We have a high degree of confidence in our playbook and in the leaders of our 13 business units who are accountable for delivering the results. The first directive is superior revenue growth. Our 2010 target is more than 10% increase versus 2009. An important foundation for our growth continues to be market-driven science. In the first quarter, we introduced 502 new products, which compares to 501 in 2009. This is an outstanding start to the year considering that last year, we set a record for new product launches in a single year. Another measure of innovation productivity is the percentage of sales from new products. Our target in 2010 is 30% sales for products that have been launched within the past four years. Recognize that this is a change from our traditional metric, where we used to define products as having been launched within the past five years. The intention behind the newly-defined metric is to push for faster, broader product launches for maximum value and return to both our customers and our shareholders. At the same time, we've been honing our product launch processes to make them more disciplined and more market focused.
Productivity remains a cornerstone of our playbook and as Nick said, we're on track versus productivity goals. And finally, our improved outlook in earnings translates to an improved outlook for cash and we expect more than $1.7 billion in free cash flow in 2010.
While first quarter recovery looks healthy, we realize there could still be a number of market scenarios that play out for the remainder of the year. Recognizing this, our business leaders have alternate business plans and a number of tactical earnings levers that they will adjust to changing market conditions, both positive and negative, and we will deliver strong results. We will continue to focus on executing the three-year playbook outlined last November and we'll do it one quarter at a time, working towards our 2012 goals with discipline and agility. At the same time, we're laying groundwork for additional growth beyond 2012. Capitalizing on the mega trends that form the backbone of today's growth plan.
We have a tremendous opportunity for investors to view firsthand the progress we're making in one of those growth areas. In two weeks on May 11, we're hosting an event in Knoxville, Tennessee, which will be entirely focused on our Applied Biosciences platform. I hope you will join me for the day. We're meeting on location in Tennessee so we can showcase two important facilities. First, our cellulosic ethanol demonstration plant and second, our production facility, where we make propanediol from corn or what we call Bio PDO. We will take you on tours of both facilities and our business leaders will talk about the opportunity we see and the progress we've made since we last updated investors two and a half years ago. I look forward to seeing you there.
Karen, I think we're ready to open the line for questions.

componenttextpreview: As you look at the Electronics segment, obviously, terrific recovery underway there. But yet, you were talking about flat or Nick was talking about flat growth in the second quarter versus the first quarter. What would be the factors behind that? Why woul
componenttext: As you look at the Electronics segment, obviously, terrific recovery underway there. But yet, you were talking about flat or Nick was talking about flat growth in the second quarter versus the first quarter. What would be the factors behind that? Why would you not anticipate seeing a continuation of the recovery there?

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We had a tremendous first quarter and the growth there has been largely driven from photovoltaics. We're not seeing restocking in the first quarter. So you're not going to have that in the second quarter. So I think sales, we see as remaining strong, but
componenttext: We had a tremendous first quarter and the growth there has been largely driven from photovoltaics. We're not seeing restocking in the first quarter. So you're not going to have that in the second quarter. So I think sales, we see as remaining strong, but by and large on a sequential basis, we'll be pretty flat. It's not going to be kind of any diminution.  It’s going to be continued strength in the electronics market, really driven off of photovoltaics. And we see that there’s, this year, we see probably about a 50% increase in our revenue from PV.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I guess the way to think about it is that the first quarter saw some restocking as well as a pickup in underlying demand whereas in the second quarter you are going to see that underlying demand pick up without the kicker of restocking.
componenttext: So I guess the way to think about it is that the first quarter saw some restocking as well as a pickup in underlying demand whereas in the second quarter you are going to see that underlying demand pick up without the kicker of restocking.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010

componenttext: Exactly, Frank. Thank you.

componenttextpreview: Ellen, on AcreMax, are you expecting the approval at 10% refuge reduction and are you actually selling acre maxes here or are you just in some test plots with farmers? Can you describe what's happening with 2,600 test plots out there?
componenttext: Ellen, on AcreMax, are you expecting the approval at 10% refuge reduction and are you actually selling acre maxes here or are you just in some test plots with farmers? Can you describe what's happening with 2,600 test plots out there?

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The EPA has not announced their decision. We haven't seen the registration. We do expect it within the next week. They've been -- the discussions have been very consistent and positive, supporting both Refuge-in-a-Bag and refuge reduction. So it's not onl
componenttext: The EPA has not announced their decision. We haven't seen the registration. We do expect it within the next week. They've been -- the discussions have been very consistent and positive, supporting both Refuge-in-a-Bag and refuge reduction. So it's not only, it's the convenience factor in there as well. Now if I were to guess and anticipate based off the discussions, I'd call it at a 90-10 product. The hot end -- those products yield very, very well versus their conventional counterparts. So we're going to have it out and demonstration plots probably over 2,600 plots this year so that farmers can really understand the yield and the capability of this product. So we're very excited about it.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've always had a strategy of value pricing, right product, right acre that has worked very well for us. It's a competitive market out there, but I think our direct to farmer model, our value-based pricing continues to be our strategy and I think that wi
componenttext: We've always had a strategy of value pricing, right product, right acre that has worked very well for us. It's a competitive market out there, but I think our direct to farmer model, our value-based pricing continues to be our strategy and I think that will serve us well this year and in the future.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010

componenttext: Our next question is from Laurence Alexander from Jefferies.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010

componenttext: This is Amanda Sigouin on for Laurence this morning. First off a question on the Seed business. Does DuPont have firm market share targets that it plans to defend if competitors become more aggressive in going after share?

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: This year is pretty much played out. Half the seed is in the ground and corn and farmers have pretty much made their decision. So we see that there's going to be this year is going to continue to progress the way it has. It's tough to predict what 2011 wi
componenttext: This year is pretty much played out. Half the seed is in the ground and corn and farmers have pretty much made their decision. So we see that there's going to be this year is going to continue to progress the way it has. It's tough to predict what 2011 will bring because that basically has to build off of what happens in 2010. So we're sticking to our playbook, right product, right acre. The penetration that we're getting, we expect to see one to two points in share again globally and we think that based on what we've seen so far in the year, we're still confident in those estimates.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could we please revisit the trajectory for the Pharmaceuticals business, particularly how fast earnings are expected to decelerate in 2011 and 2012?
componenttext: Could we please revisit the trajectory for the Pharmaceuticals business, particularly how fast earnings are expected to decelerate in 2011 and 2012?

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you know, we're now seeing that Pharma's going to be about $360 million to $400 million impact for the full year and we saw $221 million of that in the first quarter. So the remainder will be split evenly over each of the remaining quarters. So a third
componenttext: As you know, we're now seeing that Pharma's going to be about $360 million to $400 million impact for the full year and we saw $221 million of that in the first quarter. So the remainder will be split evenly over each of the remaining quarters. So a third in each of the remaining quarters is our expectation. And as you know, Pharma was down about $0.02 year-over-year in earnings per share in the first quarter. Now for the full year, we had about $1 billion in prior year and as I say, we're expecting about $360 million to $400 million this year so you can see the impact is about that $600 million for the full year and then as you go forward into 2011, you can take the number that I'm talking about now and you can go by about half and then in 2012, by about half again.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010

componenttext: Our next question is from P.J. Juvekar from Citi.

componenttext: Just quickly on AcreMax, just a follow up, with all these extra 2,600 plots that you are demonstrating your technology and you got an extra year to prepare, which is 2010, how big would your launch be in 2011 for AcreMax?

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're not going to predict that at this point. Our goal this year is to really allow thousands of farmers to see the yields and the productivity that AcreMax 1 provides and I think that is really going to build the excitement around what we can do
componenttext: I think we're not going to predict that at this point. Our goal this year is to really allow thousands of farmers to see the yields and the productivity that AcreMax 1 provides and I think that is really going to build the excitement around what we can do in 2011.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on M&A, now that some of these businesses have rebounded strongly, would you expect divesting some of the more commodity-oriented businesses to move the portfolio up the value chain?
componenttext: Just on M&A, now that some of these businesses have rebounded strongly, would you expect divesting some of the more commodity-oriented businesses to move the portfolio up the value chain?

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at our M&A strategy, really, it remains very consistent. When from an acquisition standpoint, when we look at the opportunity for acquiring potential businesses, we stay along the lines of an acquisition would be for something really of prov
componenttext: When you look at our M&A strategy, really, it remains very consistent. When from an acquisition standpoint, when we look at the opportunity for acquiring potential businesses, we stay along the lines of an acquisition would be for something really of providing significant strategic value, either technology, a value chain etc. It's not for just bulking up. On the divestitures side, which is really I think the heart of your question, we put a lot of effort, time and money into restructuring these businesses and we really believe that right now is a time where we can extract a lot of that value as we move forward. And I would really not want to give up on that opportunity and that value that we can create now with those businesses. So I really believe that from this point, from my vantage point, looking at those, we create the greatest shareholder value by continuing to run those businesses and take advantage of the leverage that we've created.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Don Carson with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from Don Carson with UBS.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question on some of the assumptions just behind your guidance, I mean clearly you're going to exceed your 10% revenue growth target. Just wondering what revenue growth is implicit in your new guidance? And with raw materials rising, do you have the
componenttext: Just a question on some of the assumptions just behind your guidance, I mean clearly you're going to exceed your 10% revenue growth target. Just wondering what revenue growth is implicit in your new guidance? And with raw materials rising, do you have the pricing power to maintain increases in variable margin? Or is this earnings growth still going to come primarily through operating leverage?

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly, we have had a great first quarter. And we're at a rate that's far greater than the 10% earnings growth that we talk about, sales growth, I'm sorry. When you look at quarter two, we have very good visibility towards quarter two and we're expecti
componenttext: Certainly, we have had a great first quarter. And we're at a rate that's far greater than the 10% earnings growth that we talk about, sales growth, I'm sorry. When you look at quarter two, we have very good visibility towards quarter two and we're expecting, as we mentioned, continued strength in the second quarter. Beyond that, third and fourth quarter, it's not as clear, obviously, as to the top line growth and what we're going to see within the market conditions. We don't anticipate any major softening. We have some very good bellwether businesses within the corporation, like our Tio2 business, and it's operating very strong. Not only is our business operating strong, but the whole industry is. So we're anticipating continued strong economy, but the visibility beyond the second half is a bit hazier, beyond the first half is a bit hazier. So at this point in time, I would stay with our greater than 10% top line growth in the year.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up on price variable cost, you really are pricing up despite cost being down. I know Tio2 is pretty tight, but what’s sort of the general pricing power within your businesses or is this just due more to your continued focus on the DuPo
componenttext: And just a follow-up on price variable cost, you really are pricing up despite cost being down. I know Tio2 is pretty tight, but what’s sort of the general pricing power within your businesses or is this just due more to your continued focus on the DuPont pricing model?

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Internally, it's a combination. I mean we instituted pricing for value for some time now and we have that discipline institutionalized through all of our businesses. So we really do take advantage of that and make sure we get the value for the innovation
componenttext: Internally, it's a combination. I mean we instituted pricing for value for some time now and we have that discipline institutionalized through all of our businesses. So we really do take advantage of that and make sure we get the value for the innovation that we're bringing to the marketplace. So there's certainly that component of it. And then there are businesses that are very tight right now. When you look at our Tio2 business, very tight in capacity. Our polymers business, our refrigerants, all those have very high aesthetes right now.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010

componenttext: Well I mean that's still playing out as we speak. I mean it looks like corn will probably plant a little more this year than maybe we had estimated earlier in this year and soy will come in late. But I think that we're on track with what we had predicted. What our estimates were this year and I'd really think that globally, we do see that 1% to 2% points of share come in our direction.

componenttextpreview: When we get the registration from the EPA, which we expect in a week, our expectation, our discussions with them indicate that the 90-10 is probable at least in the way I'm calling it now. So that's the product we will be getting out in the bag into the m
componenttext: When we get the registration from the EPA, which we expect in a week, our expectation, our discussions with them indicate that the 90-10 is probable at least in the way I'm calling it now. So that's the product we will be getting out in the bag into the marketplace and get those demonstration plots in this year. So that's going to provide us with the opportunity to show the real value to the growers of not only its yield, but its convenience that will be used to greatly support our 2011 commercial launch.

componenttextpreview: It's quite clear the recovery is significantly stronger than anticipated in November. You brought forward your photovoltaic revenue target from 2012 to 2011. So how do these results maybe reflect in your 2012 targets you could have in November?
componenttext: It's quite clear the recovery is significantly stronger than anticipated in November. You brought forward your photovoltaic revenue target from 2012 to 2011. So how do these results maybe reflect in your 2012 targets you could have in November?

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, one quarter, we're very excited about what we've been able to deliver in the quarter, both from a volume and from a productivity side, but I think we need to see a little more play out this year before we adjust the targets that we put out in N
componenttext: Well, yes, one quarter, we're very excited about what we've been able to deliver in the quarter, both from a volume and from a productivity side, but I think we need to see a little more play out this year before we adjust the targets that we put out in November of 2009. We're probably be getting together with you guys in the fourth quarter like we do every year and at that point, I think it would be very appropriate for us to give you our thinking then.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I suppose the only division where margins were slightly weaker than anticipated was Performance Coatings we’re just going to mark the target of 10% to 12% in 2012 and it's still early days but were the margins this quarter more due to the mix effect
componenttext: And I suppose the only division where margins were slightly weaker than anticipated was Performance Coatings we’re just going to mark the target of 10% to 12% in 2012 and it's still early days but were the margins this quarter more due to the mix effect in terms of more OEM revenue Refinished or do you feel you're on track for the 10% to 12% margin still?

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at that business and the slight drop in margin that you saw in the quarter, it's really due to mix, as you said, the Refinished versus the OEM mix. And it's also due to some of the raw material increases that they started to experience alrea
componenttext: When you look at that business and the slight drop in margin that you saw in the quarter, it's really due to mix, as you said, the Refinished versus the OEM mix. And it's also due to some of the raw material increases that they started to experience already in the quarter around monomers and solvents of that nature. So they’re starting to see some of that compression occur in the margin in the first quarter here.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Mark Gulley from Soleil Securities.
componenttext: Next question is from Mark Gulley from Soleil Securities.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, with respect to the competitiveness in the Seeds business, we’ve certainly talked about that a fair amount and yet you saw a 5% increase overall in this segment. So how does that square up with the competitiveness. And second, Nick, I had
componenttext: First of all, with respect to the competitiveness in the Seeds business, we’ve certainly talked about that a fair amount and yet you saw a 5% increase overall in this segment. So how does that square up with the competitiveness. And second, Nick, I had a question on continued pension contributions both this year and perhaps even next year.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: On competitiveness in Seeds, we've seen the first quarter start. It's based off of strong North American opportunity and weaker Europe opportunity than we had projected early. Europe will come in strong in the second half and we'll have a strong finish to
componenttext: On competitiveness in Seeds, we've seen the first quarter start. It's based off of strong North American opportunity and weaker Europe opportunity than we had projected early. Europe will come in strong in the second half and we'll have a strong finish to North America. So I think you'll see a second quarter strengthening in Seeds as we have discussed earlier. And I think that that's consistent with what we're seeing playing out in the planting today. So I think that overall, production agriculture is always a first-half story and it's always difficult to call first quarter, second quarter, and I think you'll see from a first half standpoint a very strong positioning.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the pension, let me just refresh everyone's memory. The $400 million that we're taking to earnings this year in the way of pension is not a cash impact item. It's just an earnings impact item. For cash impact or cash contribution this year to the pensi
componenttext:
On the pension, let me just refresh everyone's memory. The $400 million that we're taking to earnings this year in the way of pension is not a cash impact item. It's just an earnings impact item. For cash impact or cash contribution this year to the pension plan, our preliminary estimates when we look at the funding requirements needed by the Pension Protection Act of the 96% level, we believe we'll be meeting that level without having to make any cash contributions outside of the U.S. plan.
[Audio Gap]

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The last question is from Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan.
componenttext: The last question is from Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you have any targets to deploy free cash outside of paying dividends?
componenttext: Do you have any targets to deploy free cash outside of paying dividends?

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have a dividend policy which is pretty well articulated and known. We return our excess cash to our shareholders unless we have compelling investment opportunities. Our dividend issuance, we have a range in about 25% to 45% of our cash flow from operat
componenttext: We have a dividend policy which is pretty well articulated and known. We return our excess cash to our shareholders unless we have compelling investment opportunities. Our dividend issuance, we have a range in about 25% to 45% of our cash flow from operations. We'd like to stay within that range. Ultimately obviously, the dividend policy is a board decision. Outside of dividends, when you look at the growth opportunities that we have within the corporation and you look at the opportunities that we spend some of our fixed cost on our cash and capital dollars on this year, this quarter, it's reflective of the tremendous growth opportunities we have. So I believe the cash will be put to tremendous use.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: If it were the case that currency stay where they are today for a longer period of time, would that in any way impair your 2012 earnings guidance? Or are the underlying operations strong enough to go through that?
componenttext: If it were the case that currency stay where they are today for a longer period of time, would that in any way impair your 2012 earnings guidance? Or are the underlying operations strong enough to go through that?

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that we're anticipating a little bit of a headwinds of currency in the second half of the year.
componenttext: I think that we're anticipating a little bit of a headwinds of currency in the second half of the year.

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: From this point on we're actually anticipating a headwind in the currency. Currency right now in the euro, for example, is $1.33 and our assumptions are in the $1.34-ish range. So we're seeing some headwinds for the rest of this year. It's difficult to pr
componenttext: From this point on we're actually anticipating a headwind in the currency. Currency right now in the euro, for example, is $1.33 and our assumptions are in the $1.34-ish range. So we're seeing some headwinds for the rest of this year. It's difficult to project that out beyond. It's difficult even for the rest of the year, let alone into 2011 .

headline: EI DuPont de Nemours & Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010

componenttext: So that brings us to a wrap. Thank you, everybody for joining us this morning, and we're anxious to answer your questions that you have and follow up.
